metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of fractional vegetation cover and biomass observed in the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin (2014)
metadata.description:
This data includes the coverage data set of vegetation in one growth cycle in five stations of Daman super station, wetland, desert, desert and Gobi, and the biomass data set of maize and wetland reed in one growth cycle in Daman super station. The observation time starts from May 10, 2014 and ends on September 11, 2014.            
1 coverage observation            
1.1 observation time            
1.1.1 super station: the observation period is from May 10 to September 11, 2014. Before July 20, the observation is once every five days. After July 20, the observation is once every 10 days. A total of 17 observations are made. The specific observation time is as follows:;            
Super stations: May 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 10, 15, 20, 20, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 7, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 15            
1.1.2 other four stations: the observation period is from May 20 to September 15, 2014, once every 10 days, and 11 observations have been made in total. The specific observation time is as follows:;            
Other four stations: May 10, 2014, May 20, 2014, May 30, 2014, June 10, 2014, June 20, 2014, June 30, July 10, 2014, July 20, August 5, 2014, August 17, 2014, September 11, 2014            
1.2 observation method            
1.2.1 measuring instruments and principles:            
The digital camera is placed on the instrument platform at the front end of the simple support pole to keep the shooting vertical and downward and remotely control the camera measurement data. The observation frame can be used to change the shooting height of the camera and realize targeted measurement for different types of vegetation.            
1.2.2 design of sample            
Super station: take 3 plots in total, the sample size of each plot is 10 × 10 meters, take photos along two diagonal lines in turn each time, take 9-10 photos in total;            Wetland station: take 2 sample plots, each plot is 10 × 10 meters in size, and take 9-10 photos for each survey;            
3 other stations: select 1 sample plot, each sample plot is 10 × 10 meters in size, and take 9-10 photos for each survey;            
1.2.3 shooting method            
For the super station corn and wetland station reed, the observation frame is directly used to ensure that the camera on the observation frame is far higher than the vegetation crown height. Samples are taken along the diagonal in the square quadrat, and then the arithmetic average is made. In the case of a small field angle (< 30 °), the field of view includes more than 2 ridges with a full cycle, and the side length of the photo is parallel to the ridge; in the other three sites, due to the relatively low vegetation, the camera is directly used to take pictures vertically downward (without using the bracket).            
1.2.4 coverage calculation            
The coverage calculation is completed by Beijing Normal University, and an automatic classification method is adopted. For details, see article 1 of "recommended references". By transforming RGB color space to lab space which is easier to distinguish green vegetation, the histogram of green component A is clustered to separate green vegetation and non green background, and the vegetation coverage of a single photo is obtained. The advantage of this method lies in its simple algorithm, easy to implement and high degree of automation and precision. In the future, more rapid, automatic and accurate classification methods are needed to maximize the advantages of digital camera methods.            
2 biomass observation            
2.1 observation time            
2.1.1 corn: the observation period is from May 10 to September 11, 2014, once every 5 days before July 20, and once every 10 days after July 20. A total of 17 observations have been made. The specific observation time is as follows:;            
Super stations: May 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 10, 15, 20, 20, 30, 30, 30, 30, 30, 7, 10, 10, 10, 10, 10, 15            
2.1.2 Reed: the observation period is from May 20 to September 15, 2014, once every 10 days, and 11 observations have been made in total. The specific observation time is as follows:;  2014-5-10、2014-5-20、2014-5-30、2014-6-10、2014-6-20、2014-6-30、2014-7-10、2014-7-20、2014-8-5、2014-8-17、2014-9-11            
2.2 observation method            
Corn: select three sample plots, and select three corn plants that represent the average level of each sample plot for each observation, respectively weigh the fresh weight (aboveground biomass + underground biomass) and the corresponding dry weight (85 ℃ constant temperature drying), and calculate the biomass of unit area corn according to the plant spacing and row spacing;            
Reed: set two 0.5m × 0.5m quadrats, cut them in the same place, and weigh the fresh weight (stem and leaf) and dry weight (constant temperature drying at 85 ℃) of reed respectively.            
2.3 observation instruments            
Balance (accuracy 0.01g), oven.            
3 data storage            
All the observation data were recorded in the excel table first, and then stored in the excel table. At the same time, the data of corn planting structure was sorted out, including the plant spacing, row spacing, planting time, irrigation time, except for the parent time, harvesting time and other relevant information.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Are the challenges in collecting multiscale observations in this domain more related to instrumentation, data processing, or data availability?

Concept Completion.Question: What methods are used for measuring vegetation coverage in eco-hydrological studies?
What instruments are employed in the collection of biomass data, and how is the data processed?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure vegetation coverage and biomass in eco-hydrological studies?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method for measuring vegetation coverage and biomass involves using digital cameras to take photos of vegetation within designated plots. These photos are taken from a vertical downward angle using a camera mounted on a support platform. This method is used to calculate vegetation coverage through image analysis, and biomass measurements are taken by weighing selected plant samples for fresh and dry weight calculations.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of challenges faced in collecting multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in collecting multiscale observations is the poor availability of multiscale data, which hinders progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. Addressing this challenge involves designing experiments, such as HiWATER, that use hierarchical instrumentation and a sparse network of observation stations to capture data at various scales.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset that integrates multiple observational technologies to study eco-hydrological processes?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset integrating multiple observational technologies is the HiWATER dataset, which combines flux observation matrices from eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, eco-hydrological sensors for soil moisture and leaf area index, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, and ground measurements of vegetation dynamics. This multiscale dataset aims to study eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert area.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'coverage observation' in the context of eco-hydrological data collection?
Definition.Answer: Coverage observation refers to the method of measuring vegetation coverage using digital photography. In this context, a digital camera is mounted on an instrument platform and controlled remotely to capture images of vegetation from above. These images are used to calculate the percentage of ground covered by vegetation by converting RGB color space to Lab space to distinguish green vegetation from the non-vegetative background.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods for measuring vegetation coverage using digital cameras compare to multiscale observations in the HiWATER experiment?
Comparison.Answer: The digital camera method involves taking vertical downward photographs to measure vegetation coverage, utilizing an automatic classification method to calculate coverage. In contrast, the HiWATER experiment uses a hierarchical system with flux observation matrices and eco-hydrological sensor networks to capture multiscale processes, integrating various instruments like LiDAR and imaging spectrometers.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies could be employed to improve the classification and analysis of vegetation cover data collected through digital photography in eco-hydrological studies?
Interpretation.Answer: Improving the classification and analysis of vegetation cover data can be achieved by using automated classification methods that convert RGB color space to Lab space, facilitating the separation of green vegetation from non-green backgrounds. This enhances the precision of vegetation cover estimates and supports the development of more advanced, rapid, and accurate classification algorithms.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of conducting multiscale eco-hydrological observations in heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity arises from the need to capture eco-hydrological processes across different scales and landscapes, such as oasis-desert interactions, requiring a combination of hierarchically nested instrumentation and a sparse network of observation stations.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of digital cameras for vegetation coverage measurement affect the precision and automation of data collection in eco-hydrological research?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of digital cameras enhances precision and automation in data collection by allowing for simple, easy-to-implement methods with high accuracy. The technique involves converting RGB color space to the Lab space to distinguish green vegetation, which simplifies the process and improves the automatic classification of vegetation coverage.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might arise from employing a combination of ground-based measurements and remote sensing technologies in eco-hydrological studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing a combination of ground-based measurements and remote sensing technologies can result in comprehensive datasets that capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes. This integration allows for detailed observations of vegetation dynamics and provides a robust framework for understanding interactions in oasis-desert systems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential implications of using multiscale observations for understanding interactions between oasis and desert landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Multiscale observations can lead to a deeper understanding of oasis-desert interactions by capturing data across hierarchically nested scales. This approach facilitates the examination of eco-hydrological processes, such as vegetation dynamics and water distribution, contributing to a more holistic view of these complex environments.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the objective of employing digital photography techniques for vegetation coverage observation in eco-hydrological studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to utilize digital photography as a measurement tool to capture vegetation coverage data efficiently, enabling targeted measurements for different vegetation types by using an automated classification method for high accuracy and automation.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind integrating both ground measurements and airborne remote sensing in eco-hydrological research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to obtain comprehensive data that covers both detailed ground-level observations and broader landscape-level insights using remote sensing technologies, facilitating a better understanding of eco-hydrological dynamics over different spatial scales.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is biomass measured for different vegetation types in field research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: For corn, biomass measurement involves selecting representative plants within sample plots and weighing both fresh and dry biomass after drying at a constant temperature of 85°C. The unit area biomass is calculated considering plant spacing and row spacing. For reeds, biomass is measured by cutting vegetation within a set quadrat, and both fresh and dry weights are measured. The instruments used include a precision balance and an oven for drying.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to ensure the accuracy and reliability of data collected in eco-hydrological experiments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data accuracy and reliability are ensured through careful quality control processes, which include sensor calibration, systematic data collection, processing, and dataset generation. The use of multiscale and multidisciplinary instrumentation, such as eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing technologies, helps in capturing comprehensive and accurate data. Moreover, data is stored systematically in Excel files after initial manual recording, which includes metadata such as planting structure and important agricultural timings for context.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the use of digital cameras for measuring vegetation cover in eco-hydrological studies?
Enablement.Answer: The use of digital cameras mounted on an instrument platform allows for vertical downward photography, which can be remotely controlled to collect data. Adjusting the camera's shooting height enables targeted measurements for different vegetation types. The data is processed using an automated classification method, converting RGB to Lab color space for easier distinction of green vegetation, which increases automation and precision.

Enablement.Question: How do hierarchical and nested scales in instrument arrangement enable comprehensive data collection for eco-hydrological processes?
Enablement.Answer: Hierarchical and nested scales allow for capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes by arranging instruments like flux observation matrices and automatic meteorological stations at various scales. This includes sparse networks for oasis-desert interaction studies and intensive observations at the irrigation district level, facilitating detailed data collection across different landscape types.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of digital cameras and remote control for data collection be particularly effective in monitoring vegetation cover in diverse landscapes?
Expectation.Answer: The use of digital cameras and remote control allows for targeted and efficient data collection by enabling vertical downward shooting, which captures a comprehensive view of vegetation cover. This method supports the collection of detailed imagery across different vegetation types and terrains, providing high automation and precision in calculating vegetation coverage using advanced classification methods.

Expectation.Question: Why could the scarcity of multiscale observations hinder progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes?
Expectation.Answer: Multiscale observations are crucial for capturing the complex interactions within eco-hydrological processes across different scales. Without these observations, it becomes challenging to understand and model these processes comprehensively, especially in heterogeneous surfaces like the oasis-desert systems, which require data from various scales to accurately reflect their dynamics.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are the data collection methods using digital cameras in capturing accurate vegetation coverage in heterogeneous environments?
Judgmental.Answer: The data collection methods using digital cameras are effective in capturing vegetation coverage as they utilize a simple, easy-to-implement, and highly automated classification method that converts RGB color space to Lab space to distinguish green vegetation. However, there is a need for more rapid, automated, and accurate classification methods to maximize the advantages of using digital cameras.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the integration of multiscale datasets contribute to better understanding eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of multiscale datasets, such as those obtained from flux observation matrices, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, can contribute to a better understanding of eco-hydrological processes by capturing interactions at different scales. This approach allows for comprehensive monitoring and analysis of vegetation dynamics, soil moisture, and photosynthesis processes, providing a holistic view of the oasis-desert interplay.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how digital cameras can effectively measure vegetation coverage in diverse ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: Digital cameras are used to capture images from directly above the vegetation. These images are then processed using an automatic classification method that converts RGB color space to Lab space, distinguishing green vegetation from non-green backgrounds. This method is simple, automated, and precise for calculating vegetation coverage.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in collecting multiscale observational data for eco-hydrological research.
Assertion.Answer: Collecting multiscale observational data is challenging due to the limited availability of such observations. HiWATER addresses this by using hierarchically nested scales, including superstations and various sensor networks, to capture eco-hydrological processes across different landscapes and scales.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how biomass is accurately measured in field conditions.
Assertion.Answer: Biomass is measured by selecting representative sample plots, harvesting vegetation, and weighing both fresh and dry weight. For corn, the unit area biomass is calculated based on plant spacing, while for reeds, weights are measured from cut samples. This approach ensures accurate representation of biomass in the field.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the methodologies used for observing and calculating vegetation cover and biomass in different ecological stations within a heterogeneous surface.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodologies include using digital cameras for vegetation cover measurement by taking vertical downward photographs with a camera mounted on an observation frame. The observation frame allows adjustment of the camera height based on vegetation type. For biomass measurement, selected sample plots for corn and reed are used, and fresh and dry weights are measured using precision balances and ovens. Coverage calculation is performed using an automatic classification method that converts RGB to Lab color space and separates vegetation from the background based on histogram clustering.
